frontmatterData.title: Abemaciclib
frontmatterData.description: Abemaciclib is a selective kinase inhibitor that works as a targeted therapy. Specifically, this treatment is given to patients with breast cancer. The specific type of proteins, cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 (CDK 4, 6), promote cancer cells to grow and spread. Abemaciclib slows down or stops the growth and spread of cancer cells by blocking the activity of CDK 4, 6.

commonSideEffects.name: Diarrhoea
commonSideEffects.description: This treatment may disturb the intestinal lining and cause loose, watery, and more frequent stools than usual. Certain medications have a higher chance of causing diarrhoea.

commonSideEffects.name: Fatigue
commonSideEffects.description: You may feel tired and find it harder to do daily chores/activities that you usually do or want to do. It may be physical, emotional and mental exhaustion.

commonSideEffects.name: Effects on the liver
commonSideEffects.description: This medication can cause liver toxicity, which your oncology care team may monitor with blood tests called liver function tests.

commonSideEffects.name: Nausea and/or vomiting
commonSideEffects.description: Every patient reacts differently to cancer medication. Many people feel nauseous, and some also experience vomiting. Nausea and vomiting can be managed or reduced with medication.

commonSideEffects.name: Low red blood cell count (anaemia)
commonSideEffects.description: Red blood cells (RBC) are responsible for carrying oxygen to the tissues in your body. When you have a low RBC count, you may feel tired or weak and have pale skin.

commonSideEffects.name: Low white blood cell count (Leukopenia or Neutropenia)
commonSideEffects.description: White blood cells (WBC) are crucial for fighting infection. While receiving treatment, your WBC count can drop, putting you at a higher risk of disease.

commonSideEffects.name: Lungs/breathing problems
commonSideEffects.description: Chest pain, cough, shortness of breath, fever

commonSideEffects.name: Hair loss (alopecia)
commonSideEffects.description: This treatment causes the hair on your head and other body parts to fall. In most cases, hair loss is temporary, and hair grows back to normal after treatment.

commonSideEffects.name: Abdominal pain
commonSideEffects.description: Pain may be achy or cramp-like and is associated with increased flatulence (gas). Chemotherapy may also alter the normal bacterial flora in the intestines. This can affect digestion and cause abdominal pain, cramping or flatulence (gas).

commonSideEffects.name: Mouth sores
commonSideEffects.description: Cancer medications can cause sores in the mouth and throat. These sores are painful and may become infected.

commonSideEffects.name: Low appetite
commonSideEffects.description: Appetite loss or poor appetite are common side effects of cancer and its treatment. This means you may eat less than usual, not feel hungry, or feel full after eating only a tiny amount.
